awd_titl_txt: Control-Based Adaptive Characterization of Nano-scale Mechanical and Structural Properties of Biological Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to simultaneously map the mechanical properties, and characterize the structure, of a biological sample using a scanning probe microscope (SPM). The main part of the SPM is a cantilever, that may be visualized as a miniature diving board with a sharp tip attached to the underside of the free end. The fixed end of the cantilever is moved up and down in a controlled way, as a sample is passed under the sharp tip. The challenge addressed by this project is to infer both the surface topography and the mechanical properties of the sample from the way the cantilever bends as it is moved up and down, and the sample moves beneath it. Extracting this data is challenging,  because it can be difficult to separate the influences of the different components of the forces exerted by the moving surface. Use of the SPM on biological materials is further complicated by operational limits needed to avoid damaging delicate samples, and by the need to sometimes characterize samples in a liquid environment. This project considers how the excitation motion may be adjusted based on the cantilever response to provide the best possible measurement. Changes in mechanical properties of biological samples have been related to the progression of numerous diseases, including fibrosis, cancer initiation and metastasis. The ability to reliably measure these properties will advance diagnostic tests for these conditions. The project includes outreach to middle- and high-school students through tours and presentations under well-established programs at Iowa State University.
 
This project aims to improve the performance and build new functions of scanning probe microscopes (SPM) in poro- and visco- elasticity mapping of a broad variety of biological materials, using control-based approaches. The specific objectives are to (1) formulate a nanomechanical characterization methodology with optimal excitation force design to enable excitation of sample visco- and poro- elastic behavior; (2) build a new control-based adaptive SPM imaging technique with sample deformation quantification and real time force and speed optimization based on optimal output transition design; (3) achieve high-speed nanomechanical property mapping through formulating new data-driven inversion-based control approach to compensate for dynamics coupling and system uncertainty; and (4) implement and evaluate the nanomechanical property mapping scheme on SPM and then to develop an integrated software platform to synchronize the SPM mapping with optical-based bio-structure quantification.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
These project developed a suite of tools to simultaneously map the mechanical properties, and characterize the structure, of a biological sample, such as live cells, using a scanning probe microscope (SPM). The advantages of using SPM for biological material dynamic behavior studies are the superior spatial and force resolution of this type of instruments. However, the outstanding sensitivity and accuracy of SPM come with the complicated hardware nonlinear dynamics. Extracting the material behavior data from SPM operation is challenging, because it can be difficult to separate the influences of the different components of the forces exerted by the moving surfaces of the SPM probe and the sample. Use of the SPM on biological materials is further complicated by operational limits needed to avoid damaging delicate samples, and by the need to sometimes characterize samples in a liquid environment. This project developed tools to adjust the SPM excitation motion based on the SPM cantilever response to provide the best possible nano-biological characterization. This project led to significant improvement of the SPM performance and built new functions in poro- and visco- elasticity mapping of a broad variety of biological materials, including live cells.

Specifically, a nanomechanical characterization methodology with optimal excitation force design was formulated using machine learning (ML)-based approaches. ML neural networks were train using the SPM force-indentation data measured on live cells and soft polymers, such as hydro gel and PDMS. The ultimate purpose of using ML approaches, i.e, data-drive approaches, is that no analytical modeling approaches can be sufficient enough to reflect the complex nonlinear frequency and amplitude dependent behavior of live cells. With the ML learning models, optimal force, e.g., the output of these models, were able to be generated excite the sample visco- and poro- elastic behavior while maintaining the sample integrity. 

Meanwhile, new control-based adaptive SPM imaging techniques were built with sample deformation quantification and real time force and speed optimization for SPM operation. Through seamless integration of data-driven modeling and real-time feedback control approaches , such as model predictive control, the complex SPM nonlinear dynamics and system uncertainties were compensated. Thus, SPM performance was improved significantly in terms of both accuracy and speed. 

Therefore, these modeling and control-based tools developed in this project resulted in characterization of nano-scale mechanical and structural properties of biological materials with ultra accuracy and speed. These newly build tools were implemented and evaluated on a commercial platform for nanomechanical property mapping of different types of cells, such as fibroblast cells, epithelial cells, and endothelial cells.

Changes in mechanical properties of biological samples have been related to the progression of numerous diseases, including fibrosis, cancer initiation and metastasis. The ability to reliably measure these properties will advance diagnostic tests for these conditions. Specifically, the ML-based modeling approach developed is the first of its kind that models relation between the cellular cytoskeleton morphology and the cellular mechanical behavior. It directly leads to more accurate living cell mechanotrasduction quantification, and will serve as a fundamental tool in cellular biomechanical characterization studies. Moreover, this this data-based machine learning model, researcher can estimate the cell mechanical behavior just use the optical cytoskeleton data (such as the result of our previously developed image recognition tool) as the input to this model. The data-driven control algorithms we developed are capable of accounting for both the nonlinear hysteresis and creep effect of nano-positioning devices with optimal computation efficiency. The control accuracy achieved is comparable to that of offline controllers (such as iterative learning control), therefore, it can be broadly used in tracking control of nanopositioning devices, such as those used in nano/micro-manufacturing.

This project has encouraged both graduate and undergraduate students to participate in the development and implementation of the cell system dynamics research using SPM, especially female students. The research data and software tools developed helped to enrich both the undergraduate and graduate curriculum in the dynamics and controls area of Iowa State University. Supported by this project, the PI's research group reached out to K-12 students through hosting lab tours, participating research exhibitions, and research outcomes presentations.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2022
Modified by: Juan Ren
